clusters.description: CES is a mis-specified/over-smooth model for AI R&D progress: mapping a static CES production function onto dynamic, path-dependent, thresholdy research progress is unjustified, so the derived ceilings/"late bottleneck" results are artifacts.
The paper’s conclusions are highly sensitive to fixed/assumed parameters (especially α=0.5), so the numeric "max speed" ceilings are not robust and may be driven by arbitrary parameter choices.

Labor (AI researchers/agents) is not an independent input from compute: scaling L at fixed K is physically incoherent because agent cognition/inference consumes the same compute/bandwidth/infra, so the key thought experiment and substitutability claims break.
"AGIs can simulate compute in their heads" is a mirage: it double-counts compute by relabeling physical computation as labor, so it doesn’t refute complementarity or fixed-hardware constraints.

The "near-frontier experiments declined yet progress continued" inference is weak/confounded and can even support the opposite: frontier runs may be keystone anchors, and historical trends don’t falsify frontier-validation bottlenecks.

Algorithmic efficiency doesn’t automatically increase experiment throughput or loosen compute bottlenecks: savings are often spent on pushing the frontier (induced demand) or require extra validation/search, so compute can remain binding.

Small-scale/proxy experiments can’t reliably substitute for frontier validation because of scale-dependent effects and regime shifts; extrapolation fails exactly where frontier behavior/emergence matters, reinstating a hard compute gate.
"Strongest-link" / many-routes optimism fails because routes are compute-entangled and share a common compute-heavy validator (training/eval); route diversity doesn’t remove the shared bottleneck.

The paper’s rejection of low ρ via "max speed seems implausibly low" is intuition/handwaving (question-begging) rather than a calibrated argument; low ceilings could be plausible under validation-heavy/idea-scarce models.

ρ (substitutability) is not constant across regimes: as automation scales, remaining gains become more validation/compute-intensive and complementarity can increase, making compute bind earlier than the paper claims.

Reconfiguration/adaptation isn’t just "fast thinking": changing the R&D production process requires compute-heavy experimentation/validation and/or slow socio-technical steps, so AGIs can’t quickly raise ρ toward 0.

Coordination/organizational scaling overhead creates serial/merge/integration bottlenecks; adding many researchers/agents can reduce net progress and effectively tighten compute/validation constraints.
Evaluation/verification/reliability (not just training) becomes the binding bottleneck; as capability rises, assurance costs scale up and throttle validated progress even if training gets cheaper.

The SIE definition/metric ("5 OOM effective training compute in <1 year") is ambiguous or misleading: effective-compute gains may not map to capability-speed, may not compound multiplicatively, and may quietly reintroduce physical limits.
